Brandstorm Application: Show how your innovation is UNPRECEDENTED (not just better version of existing). Prove you're creating new magic, not copying old formulas.

PART 3: THE 12 SUCCESS PATTERNS

These patterns are distilled from 12 Exception fragrance benchmarks analyzed in the Exception Market Study. Innovations should integrate these proven elements.

PATTERN 1: EXCEPTIONAL JUICE IS NON-NEGOTIABLE FOUNDATION

Evidence: 100% of 12 benchmarks have olfactive excellence as foundation.

The Three Olfactive Imperatives:

1. IMMEDIATE OLFACTORY MESSAGE (Simple & Qualitative)

  • Consumer can describe scent in 1-2 words
  • Clear signature (not muddled complexity)
  • Example: Santal 33 = "Sandalwood," Black Opium = "Sweet coffee"

2. OLFACTIVE INCIDENT (Strong Partis Pris)

  • Ingredient in overdose OR unusual combination
  • Creates memorability and talkability
  • Example: Libre lavender overdose, BR540 saffron, Santal 33 violet accord

3. COMPLEX ARCHITECTURE (Drydown Revelation)

  • Deconstructed pyramid (not linear top-heart-base)
  • Reveals over time (2-8+ hours)
  • Skin chemistry interaction (unique per person)
  • Example: "Dupes clone head notes but disappoint in lastingness"

Proprietary Ingredients as Competitive Moat:

  • Osmobloom‚Ñ¢: L'Or√©al exclusive (impossible for dupes to access)
  • Rare/Expensive: Iris Pallida absolute, Oud oil, Osmanthus
  • Biotech/Sustainable: Lab-grown musk, upcycled extracts

The Perfumer's Signature:

  • Name the perfumer (expertise signal)
  • Tell their creative vision (artistry)
  • 7 years to perfect (not rushed)

Brandstorm Application: Your juice MUST be exceptional. Describe olfactive incident, drydown architecture, and proprietary ingredients. If juice is generic ‚Üí innovation will fail.

PATTERN 2: BUILD FOR 3-7 YEARS (NOT SHOOTING STAR)

Evidence: All 12 benchmarks took years to reach icon status (none were immediate overnight successes).

The Long-Term Build Strategy:

YEAR 1-2: FOUNDATION

  • Expert discovery (niche launch)
  • "Hidden treasure" status
  • Organic word-of-mouth
  • Goal: Validation, not scale

YEAR 3-4: GROWTH

  • Mainstream awareness
  • Newcomer activation
  • Bestseller ranking
  • Goal: Scale with quality perception

YEAR 5-7: ICON STATUS

  • Cultural landmark
  • Top 10 fragrance
  • Re-enchantment launched
  • Goal: Endurance, not decline

The Re-Enchantment Plan:

  • Launched at Year 3-5 (before brand fatigue)
  • Strategies: Limited editions, artist collaborations, flankers, reformulations, packaging refresh
  • Goal: Maintain Expert appeal + reignite Newcomer interest

Brandstorm Application: Present 5-year roadmap showing patient build strategy + re-enchantment plan.

PATTERN 3: BALANCE DUAL TARGET (EXPERTS FIRST, THEN NEWCOMERS)

Evidence: Successful exceptions attract both Experts (for credibility) and Newcomers (for scale).

The Progression Strategy:

PHASE 1: EXPERT DISCOVERY (Year 0-2)

  • Hooks: Confidentiality, olfactive technique, perfumer story, avant-garde scent
  • Channels: Niche boutiques, Fragrantica, Basenotes, expert influencers
  • Outcome: Validation ("This is the real deal")

PHASE 2: NEWCOMER ACTIVATION (Year 2-4)

  • Hooks: Status symbol, compliment-getter, buzzy/viral, aesthetic territory
  • Channels: #fragrancetok, Instagram, celebrity ambassadors, Sephora
  • Outcome: Scale (‚Ç¨50M+ annual sell-out)

PHASE 3: BALANCE MAINTENANCE (Year 4+)

  • Strategy: Tiered offerings (Core + Limited Editions), community programs, re-enchantment
  • Goal: Prevent Expert abandonment while sustaining Newcomer interest

Brandstorm Application: Show dual target strategy with clear progression. Explain how you retain Experts when Newcomers scale.

PATTERN 4: LEVERAGE PROPRIETARY ADVANTAGE

Evidence: L'Or√©al's distinctive assets (tech, brands, scale) are competitive moats.

L'Or√©al's Proprietary Assets:

1. OSMOBLOOM‚Ñ¢ TECHNOLOGY

  • Water-free scent extraction from living flowers
  • Can extract "mute" flowers (impossible with traditional methods)
  • Exclusivity: L'Or√©al Group only

2. BEAUTY TECH LEADERSHIP

  • Scent-Sation (AI + neuroscience)
  • Cell BioPrint (biotech efficacy testing)
  • 8,000 Digital/Tech/Data talents

3. COUTURE BRAND PORTFOLIO

  • 27 L'Or√©al Luxe brands (YSL, Lanc√¥me, Prada, Valentino, Armani, MM)
  • Authentic fashion house DNA
  • Heritage narratives dupes cannot fake

4. REFILL INFRASTRUCTURE

  • 11,000+ Mugler fountains worldwide
  • Multi-brand refill pilots (10+ locations)
  • Scale advantage (boutiques, systems, logistics)

Strategic Layering:

  • Use 2-3+ proprietary assets (not just one)
  • Example: Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ ingredient + Scent-Sation personalization + YSL heritage + Refill fountains = FOUR undupable layers

Brandstorm Application: Show which L'Or√©al proprietary advantages your innovation leverages. More layers = stronger moat.

PATTERN 5: BLEND IDENTITY + AESTHETICS (SOPHISTICATED NARRATIVE)

Evidence: Exception benchmarks have narrative depth (not just scent).

The Narrative Formula:

IDENTITY TERRITORY (Traditional Imaginaries):

  • The Gentleman, Femme Fatale, Rich Family's Old Money Daughter
  • Timeless archetypes with emotional resonance

+

AESTHETIC TERRITORY (Contemporary Codes):

  • Dark Academia, Clean Girl, Coquette, "That Girl"
  • Current cultural zeitgeist, social media-driven

=

SOPHISTICATED NARRATIVE (Unique Positioning):

  • Deeper than either alone
  • Example: YSL Libre = Femme Fatale (identity) √ó Expensive Girl (aesthetic) = Liberated Woman Who Owns Her Choices

Authenticity Requirements:

  • Rooted in real brand heritage (not marketing fiction)
  • Culturally credible (avoid appropriation)
  • Emotionally resonant (not just cool-sounding)
  • Ownable (dupes can't claim same story)

Brandstorm Application: Define your identity territory + aesthetic territory. Show how they blend into sophisticated, authentic narrative only your brand can tell.

PATTERN 6: ENGINEER STRATEGIC VIRALITY

Evidence: Virality follows specific patterns‚Äîmust-haves + amplifiers + boosters.

The Virality Formula:

MUST-HAVES (Required):

  • Scent Profile (29%): Talkable, memorable olfactive signature
  • Aesthetic Territory (24%): Visual/lifestyle codes (#DarkAcademia, #CleanGirl)

STRONG AMPLIFIERS (Boost virality):

  • Bottle Design (13%): Unboxing-worthy, Instagram-able
  • Metaphors (11%): "That Girl," "Main Character Energy," "Old Money"
  • Social Comparison (10%): Uniqueness/status signals

CELEBRITY BOOSTERS (Trigger moments):

  • Celebrity Wearing (8%): Authentic endorsement (not just paid ad)
  • Creator Partnerships (5%): @perfumerism (558K), @paulireactss (2.1M)

Strategic Virality Roadmap:

PHASE 1: SEED (Months 1-6)

  • Expert influencers discover organically
  • "Hidden treasure" positioning

PHASE 2: AMPLIFY (Months 6-18)

  • Aesthetic territory activation
  • Unboxing content, compliment stories

PHASE 3: MAINSTREAM (Months 18-36)

  • Celebrity reveal, broad retail
  • "IT fragrance" status

Brandstorm Application: Map virality strategy showing must-haves, amplifiers, and phased activation plan.

PATTERN 7: REFILLABILITY AS LUXURY RITUAL (NOT JUST ECO)

Evidence: Almost 100% of L'Or√©al Luxe bestsellers are refillable.

The Refill Philosophy:

Positioning: "Made to Last" Luxury

  • Not: "Save money/planet" (utilitarian)
  • But: "Treasure this bottle, refill as ritual" (emotional)

Refill Infrastructure Examples:

MUGLER FOUNTAIN:

  • Since 1992 (pioneer)
  • 11,000+ locations globally
  • In-store experience (sommelier service)

MULTI-BRAND REFILL:

  • Pilot: 10+ points of sale
  • YSL, Prada, Valentino, Armani (one fountain)
  • Scale advantage over single-brand systems

Design for Refill:

  • Integrated mechanism (elegant, not clunky)
  • Heavy bottle (worth keeping)
  • At-home refill option (convenience)
  • Sustainability impact (quantified: 44% less glass, etc.)

Brandstorm Application: Show refill system as luxury ritual. Explain infrastructure (in-store fountains? At-home? Both?) and sustainability impact.

PATTERN 8: PERSONALIZATION AT SCALE

Evidence: Tech enables individual relationships while reaching millions.

The Personalization Spectrum:

TIER 1: MATCHING (Recommend from existing lineup)

  • AI quiz or neuroscience test
  • "These 3 fragrances suit YOUR profile"
  • Example: YSL Scent-Sation

TIER 2: CUSTOMIZATION (Adjust formula)

  • Choose concentration, intensity, size
  • "Your version of this fragrance"

TIER 3: BESPOKE (Unique creation)

  • Perfumer crafts individual formula
  • Limited to VIP/ultra-premium

Scale Enablers:

  • AI/ML: Analyze preferences, predict matches
  • Data Infrastructure: Consumer profiles, olfactory twins
  • Beauty Tech: Neuroscience (Scent-Sation), biotech (skin chemistry analysis)

The Competitive Moat:

  • Dupes offer one-size-fits-all (generic)
  • L'Or√©al offers personalized (individual relationship)
  • Creates switching costs (your data, your profile, your community)

Brandstorm Application: Show personalization strategy (which tier?). Explain how tech enables scale while maintaining individual connection.

PATTERN 9: OMNICHANNEL EXCELLENCE (ONLINE + OFFLINE SYNERGY)

Evidence: Exception consumers research online, test offline, engage across channels.

The Consumer Journey:

DISCOVERY (Online-First):

  • TikTok video, Instagram ad, celebrity mention
  • Fragrantica research, YouTube reviews
  • Brand website exploration

EVALUATION (Offline Critical):

  • In-store scent test (olfaction can't be digitized)
  • Drydown assessment (wear for hours)
  • Boutique consultation (expert guidance)

PURCHASE (Flexible):

  • Online (convenience)
  • In-store (immediate gratification, ritual)
  • Subscription (auto-refill)

ENGAGEMENT (Ecosystem):

  • App (olfactory profile, layering tips, community)
  • Refill reminders (smart bottle, AI)
  • VIP events (exclusive access)

Omnichannel Best Practices:

  • Seamless data: Online profile connects to in-store experience
  • Unified inventory: Order online, pick up in store (BOPIS)
  • Phygital experiences: AR try-on, digital consultations, smart mirrors
  • Consistent narrative: Same brand story across all touchpoints

Brandstorm Application: Map consumer journey across online + offline touchpoints. Show how channels integrate seamlessly.

PATTERN 10: LEVERAGE COUTURE TRANSLATION

Evidence: Fashion house fragrances have authentic heritage (not generic luxury).

The Couture Advantage:

Brand DNA Translation:

  • Fashion codes ‚Üí Olfactive interpretation
  • Example: YSL Le Smoking (androgynous tuxedo) ‚Üí Libre (gender-bending lavender/orchid)

Visual to Olfactive:

  • Runway aesthetics inform fragrance bottles
  • Color palettes, materials, silhouettes
  • Example: Valentino Donna Born in Roma (pink couture codes)

Couture Brand Opportunities:

Brand Fashion DNA Fragrance Opportunity
YSL Liberation, rock chic, androgyny Gender-bending structures, rebellious narratives
Lanc√¥me French optimism, rose heritage Rose-centric, "La Vie Est Belle" positioning
Prada Intellectual luxury, minimalism Conceptual fragrances, avant-garde
Valentino Roman heritage, haute couture "Born in Roma" narrative, couture elegance
Armani Italian sophistication, tailoring Refined masculinity, understated luxury

Brandstorm Application: If using couture brand, show authentic translation of fashion DNA to fragrance. Avoid generic luxury that could be any brand.

PATTERN 11: PROACTIVE SAFETY/ETHICS/EDUCATION

Evidence: Consumer trust in L'Or√©al science differentiates from dupes.

The Trust Advantage:

WHAT DUPES LACK:

  • Safety testing (skip to reduce costs)
  • Ingredient transparency (vague formulas)
  • Ethical sourcing (questionable supply chains)
  • Regulatory compliance (cut corners)

WHAT L'OR√âAL PROVIDES:

  • Cell BioPrint: Efficacy + safety validation on bioprinted tissues (not animals)
  • Ingredient transparency: Full disclosure, provenance stories
  • Ethical sourcing: Fair remuneration, biodiversity preservation
  • Certifications: EcoVadis, Safety assessments, Regulatory approvals

Education as Differentiation:

  • Teach consumers: Why originals are safer/better
  • Behind-the-scenes: Lab tours, perfumer interviews, sourcing journeys
  • Proactive transparency: Don't wait for scandals, lead with honesty

Brandstorm Application: Show how your innovation prioritizes safety/ethics. Explain educational strategy to differentiate from dupes.

PATTERN 12: PLAN RE-ENCHANTMENT (YEAR 3-5)

Evidence: Successful exceptions plan for lifecycle evolution (not just launch).

The Re-Enchantment Strategy:

WHEN: Year 3-5 (before brand fatigue sets in)

WHY:

  • Prevent red ocean commoditization
  • Maintain Expert interest (they seek novelty)
  • Reignite Newcomer excitement (avoid "everyone has it" fatigue)

HOW (Tactics):

1. LIMITED EDITIONS

  • Seasonal variations, holiday releases
  • Artist collaborations (bottle design)
  • Numbered bottles (collectibility)

2. FLANKERS (OLFACTIVE VARIATIONS)

  • Intense/Elixir versions (higher concentration)
  • Aqua/Light versions (lighter interpretation)
  • Example: Libre ‚Üí Libre Intense ‚Üí Libre Flowers & Flames

3. PACKAGING REFRESH

  • New bottle colors/materials
  • Luxury editions (crystal, gold accents)
  • Travel/mini sizes (accessibility)

4. EXPERIENCE INNOVATION

  • New refill fountain experiences
  • Augmented reality integrations
  • Community co-creation (vote on next scent)

5. NARRATIVE EVOLUTION

  • New ambassador/celebrity
  • Updated campaign aesthetic
  • Cultural moment capture (new zeitgeist)

The 5-Year Vision:

  • Year 1-2: Launch, expert validation, foundation
  • Year 3-4: Scale, mainstream success, bestseller status
  • Year 5+: Re-enchantment launches, franchise expands, icon status

Brandstorm Application: Present 5-year roadmap including re-enchantment plan. Show you're thinking beyond launch.

FINAL INTEGRATION: USING THIS FRAMEWORK

How Brandstorm Teams Should Apply:

STEP 1: VALUES ALIGNMENT CHECK

  • Does our innovation embody Culture de l'√âcart? (twist?)
  • Does it balance Art & Science? (beauty + rigor?)
  • Is it inclusive? (who might we exclude?)
  • Is sustainability luxury (not compromise)?
  • Does it honor French heritage + achieve global reach?

STEP 2: IDEOLOGIES ADHERENCE

  • Time strategic? (3-7 year plan?)
  • Virality engineered? (must-haves + amplifiers?)
  • Dual target sequential? (Experts first?)
  • Undupable? (4+ layers?)
  • Tech enhances? (invisible magic?)
  • Sustainability = luxury? (made to last?)
  • Narrative authentic? (not fiction?)
  • Unique formula? (not copycat?)

STEP 3: SUCCESS PATTERNS INTEGRATION

  • Exceptional juice? (olfactive incident + drydown?)
  • Long-term build? (not shooting star?)
  • Dual target balance? (progression plan?)
  • Proprietary advantage? (Osmobloom‚Ñ¢, tech, brand?)
  • Sophisticated narrative? (identity + aesthetics?)
  • Strategic virality? (formula mapped?)
  • Refillability? (luxury ritual?)
  • Personalization? (at scale?)
  • Omnichannel? (online + offline?)
  • Couture translation? (if applicable)
  • Safety/ethics? (education strategy?)
  • Re-enchantment? (Year 3-5 plan?)

Scoring Your Innovation:

Category Max Points Your Score Notes
Foundational Values Alignment 20 _____ Culture de l'√âcart? Art & Science? Inclusivity? Sustainability? Heritage + Reach?
Guiding Ideologies Adherence 30 _____ All 8 ideologies considered and implemented?
Success Patterns Integration 50 _____ All 12 patterns integrated? (4 points each, partial credit OK)
TOTAL L'OR√âAL DNA SCORE 100 _____ Minimum 75 recommended for authentic L'Or√©al innovation

CONCLUSION: THE L'OR√âAL WAY

"We don't follow beauty trends. We create them."

This framework represents 60+ years of L'Or√©al Luxe fragrance excellence. By embodying these 5 values, adhering to these 8 ideologies, and integrating these 12 success patterns, your Brandstorm 2026 innovation will:

  • Embody L'Or√©al DNA (not generic luxury)
  • Capture Exception Eldorado (‚Ç¨7.5B, +29% growth)
  • Resist dupe commoditization (undupable layers)
  • Win Brandstorm (judges recognize authentic alignment)
  • Succeed in market (proven patterns = real-world viability)

Your innovation isn't just a competition entry‚Äîit's the future of luxury fragrance.

Make it worthy of L'Or√©al's legacy.

CRAFT THE FUTURE. EMBODY THE DNA.

Document Classification: Strategic Reference - For Brandstorm 2026 Teams
Preparation Date: January 2026
Purpose: Comprehensive framework of L'Or√©al values, ideologies, and success patterns
Version: 1.0

BRANDSTORM 2026 JUDGING CRITERIA & EVALUATION SYSTEM

Comprehensive Point-Based Assessment Framework


Document Version: 2.0 (Enhanced)

Preparation Date: January 2026

Purpose: Multi-layered evaluation system combining official Brandstorm criteria with strategic success predictors



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


This document provides a four-tier evaluation framework for assessing Brandstorm 2026 innovations:


TIER 1: Official Competition Criteria (50 points - 25 project + 25 team)

TIER 2: L'Or√©al Success Pattern Alignment (100 points)

TIER 3: Exception Market Potential (50 points)

TIER 4: Dupe Immunity & Defensibility (50 points)


TOTAL POSSIBLE SCORE: 250 points


WINNING THRESHOLD: 200+ points = Strong Finalist Potential



TIER 1: OFFICIAL BRANDSTORM COMPETITION CRITERIA


SECTION A: PROJECT EVALUATION (25 POINTS)


Official Framework from Mission Document:


Each project evaluated on 5 criteria, max 5 points each.



CRITERION #1: INNOVATIVE (5 POINTS)


Official Definition:

"Be bold and bring products and solutions never seen before"


Scoring Rubric:


5 POINTS - BREAKTHROUGH INNOVATION:
  • Fundamentally new approach never seen in luxury fragrance
    • Combines multiple innovations in unprecedented way
      • "Culture de l'√âcart" embodiment - true twist/disruption
        • Experts would recognize as avant-garde
          • Patent-worthy or proprietary technology involved

Examples:
  • Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ extraction (capturing previously impossible scents)
    • YSL Scent-Sation (neuroscience + AI olfactory profiling)
      • HAPTA (motion-stabilizing beauty device)

Questions to Ask:
  • Has this EVER been done before in fragrance category?
    • Would experts describe this as "revolutionary"?
      • Does it push boundaries in unexpected direction?
        • Could it create a new subcategory?


4 POINTS - HIGHLY INNOVATIVE:
  • Significant innovation with meaningful novelty
    • Adapts breakthrough from another industry to fragrance
      • Multiple innovative elements combined
        • Clear differentiation from current offerings

Examples:
  • First multi-brand refill fountain network
    • AR + AI + generative algorithms for beauty (YSL Hyper Look)
      • Lab-on-chip for skin assessment (Lanc√¥me Cell BioPrint)


3 POINTS - MODERATELY INNOVATIVE:
  • Meaningful improvement over existing approaches
    • Innovative within fragrance but not unprecedented
      • Good execution of emerging trend
        • Some novel elements

Examples:
  • Premium refillable bottles (innovative in 2020, standard by 2026)
    • Personalized fragrance quiz (cognitive science-based)
      • Sustainable ingredient sourcing


2 POINTS - INCREMENTAL INNOVATION:
  • Small improvements to existing concepts
    • Following established innovation paths
      • Safe, predictable approach
        • Limited novelty

Examples:
  • Another flanker with different concentration
    • Line extension with new scent notes
      • Packaging redesign without functional innovation


1 POINT - MINIMAL INNOVATION:
  • Barely different from existing products
    • Copying current market offerings
      • No meaningful novelty
        • "Me-too" approach


0 POINTS - NOT INNOVATIVE:
  • Identical to existing products
    • No innovation whatsoever


Innovation Sub-Criteria Breakdown:


A. PRODUCT INNOVATION (Max 2 points):
  • Novel ingredients (1 point: new, 2 points: proprietary like Osmobloom‚Ñ¢)
    • Olfactive structure innovation (1 point: unusual, 2 points: unprecedented)
      • Form factor innovation (1 point: new application, 2 points: category-creating)

B. TECH & SCIENCE INNOVATION (Max 2 points):
  • Technology integration (1 point: existing tech new use, 2 points: breakthrough tech)
    • Scientific advancement (1 point: improved process, 2 points: new discovery)
      • Personalization capability (1 point: basic, 2 points: AI-powered individual)

C. EXPERIENCE INNOVATION (Max 1 point):
  • Consumer journey (0.5 point: improved, 1 point: reimagined)
    • Service model (0.5 point: enhanced, 1 point: transformative)

Total Cap: 5 points maximum


CRITERION #2: SUSTAINABLE (5 POINTS)


Official Definition:

"Take responsibility and be mindful of the impact your project will have on the planet"


Scoring Rubric:


5 POINTS - SUSTAINABILITY LEADERSHIP:
  • Multiple sustainability dimensions addressed comprehensively
    • Circular economy model (refillable, recyclable, biodegradable)
      • Regenerative approach (improves environment, not just less harm)
        • Transparent, traceable supply chain
          • Carbon neutral or negative
            • Biodiversity preservation or enhancement
              • Industry-leading certifications achievable

Examples:
  • Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ (water-free extraction, flowers left intact, biodiversity preserved)
    • Lanc√¥me Domaine de la Rose (7 hectares organic, 280+ species refuge)
      • Prada Paradoxe refill (saves 44% glass, 67% plastic, 100% metals)

Questions:
  • Does this IMPROVE the environment (not just reduce harm)?
    • Is it circular by design (cradle-to-cradle)?
      • Does it set new industry sustainability standards?
        • Would EcoVadis Platinum recognize this?


4 POINTS - HIGHLY SUSTAINABLE:
  • Strong sustainability across multiple dimensions
    • Refillable infrastructure included
      • Reduced environmental footprint vs. industry standard (30%+ improvement)
        • Sustainable sourcing documented
          • Carbon impact measured and minimized
            • Recyclable packaging

Examples:
  • Multi-brand refill fountain integration
    • La Vie est Belle 15% weight reduction (saves 1M bottles glass/year)
      • 97% renewable energy operations


3 POINTS - MODERATELY SUSTAINABLE:
  • Meaningful sustainability efforts
    • Some refillable or recyclable elements
      • Reduced footprint vs standard (15-30% improvement)
        • Some sustainable sourcing
          • Carbon impact considered

Examples:
  • Refillable bottle without infrastructure
    • Reduced plastic content
      • Some biobased ingredients


2 POINTS - BASIC SUSTAINABILITY:
  • Minimum sustainability standards met
    • Complies with regulations
      • Some recycled content
        • Vague sustainability claims


1 POINT - MINIMAL EFFORT:
  • Token sustainability gestures
    • Greenwashing risk
      • No measurable impact


0 POINTS - NO SUSTAINABILITY:
  • No consideration of environmental impact
    • Harmful materials
      • Disposable by design


Sustainability Sub-Criteria Breakdown:


A. PRODUCT DESIGN (Max 2 points):
  • Refillable/reusable (2 points: full system, 1 point: bottle only, 0 points: disposable)
    • Materials (1 point: recycled/biobased, 0 points: virgin/harmful)
      • Durability (1 point: made to last, 0 points: single-use)

B. INGREDIENTS/FORMULA (Max 1.5 points):
  • Sourcing (1 point: sustainable/traceable, 0.5 point: some sustainable, 0 points: conventional)
    • Biodegradability (0.5 point: biodegradable formula, 0 points: not)

C. OPERATIONS & SUPPLY CHAIN (Max 1.5 points):
  • Carbon footprint (1 point: carbon neutral/negative, 0.5 point: reduced, 0 points: high)
    • Water usage (0.5 point: water-free/recycled, 0 points: high water use)

Total Cap: 5 points maximum


CRITERION #3: INCLUSIVE (5 POINTS)


Official Definition:

"Be mindful of diverse needs in our society to not exclude any particular social groups (gender, sexual orientation, socio-economic and multicultural origins, people with disability, all ages & generations), and make your project as equally accessible as possible to all potential users"


Scoring Rubric:


5 POINTS - EXEMPLARY INCLUSIVITY:
  • Designed FOR diversity from inception (not adapted)
    • Addresses multiple diversity dimensions (4+ of the following):
      • Gender & LGBTQIA+ inclusivity
        • Socio-economic accessibility
          • Multicultural sensitivity
            • Disability accommodation
              • Multi-generational appeal
                • Body type/size inclusivity
                  • Removes barriers others don't address
                    • Could become inclusion benchmark
                      • Co-created WITH diverse communities

Examples:
  • HAPTA (enables 50M people with limited motor skills)
    • YSL Scent-Sation (personalizes for every individual's unique biology)
      • Multi-generational appeal (Gen Z to Gen X different needs met)

Questions:
  • Who might be EXCLUDED by current solutions?
    • How does this actively INCLUDE them?
      • Was it co-created with diverse groups?
        • Does it remove systemic barriers?


4 POINTS - HIGHLY INCLUSIVE:
  • Strong inclusivity across 3 diversity dimensions
    • Meaningful barrier removal
      • Accessible pricing tiers or formats
        • Cultural sensitivity demonstrated
          • Some co-creation with diverse groups

Examples:
  • Fragrance layering system (personal expression across identities)
    • Multi-concentration tiers (different price points)
      • Gender-neutral positioning with diverse ambassadors


3 POINTS - MODERATELY INCLUSIVE:
  • Addresses 2 diversity dimensions
    • Some accessibility considerations
      • Doesn't exclude, but doesn't actively include
        • Standard industry inclusivity

Examples:
  • Gender-neutral scent
    • Multiple size options
      • Diverse marketing imagery


2 POINTS - BASIC INCLUSIVITY:
  • Addresses 1 dimension superficially
    • Minimum compliance with inclusivity expectations
      • May have unintentional barriers


1 POINT - MINIMAL EFFORT:
  • Token diversity in marketing
    • Product design not inclusive
      • Significant barriers remain


0 POINTS - EXCLUSIONARY:
  • Actively excludes groups
    • Discriminatory positioning
      • Accessibility ignored


Inclusivity Sub-Criteria Breakdown:


A. PRODUCT ACCESSIBILITY (Max 2 points):
  • Physical accessibility (1 point: usable by people with disabilities, 0 points: barriers exist)
    • Sensory accessibility (1 point: accounts for sensitivities, 0 points: one-size-fits-all)

B. ECONOMIC ACCESSIBILITY (Max 1.5 points):
  • Price range (1 point: multiple tiers, 0.5 point: mid-range, 0 points: ultra-premium only)
    • Value proposition (0.5 point: refillable/lasting value, 0 points: disposable luxury)

C. CULTURAL & IDENTITY INCLUSIVITY (Max 1.5 points):
  • Gender inclusivity (0.5 point: gender-neutral or multiple options)
    • Cultural sensitivity (0.5 point: respectful of diverse cultures)
      • Representation (0.5 point: co-created with or representative of diverse groups)

Total Cap: 5 points maximum


CRITERION #4: FEASIBLE (5 POINTS)


Official Definition:

"Project must be realistic and possible to implement"


Scoring Rubric:


5 POINTS - HIGHLY FEASIBLE:
  • Technology exists and is accessible
    • Cost structure realistic and profitable
      • Supply chain achievable
        • Regulatory compliance clear path
          • Timeline realistic (2-3 years to market)
            • L'Or√©al has necessary capabilities or partnerships
              • Selling price makes sense for target market
                • Business model proven or low-risk

Examples:
  • Extending existing Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ to new flowers (tech proven)
    • Expanding multi-brand refill fountain (infrastructure piloted)
      • New concentration of existing successful fragrance

Questions:
  • Does L'Or√©al already have this technology/capability?
    • Is the cost structure profitable at proposed price?
      • Can this be manufactured at scale?
        • Are there regulatory blockers?


4 POINTS - FEASIBLE WITH EFFORT:
  • Technology exists but requires adaptation
    • Cost structure needs optimization but achievable
      • Supply chain complex but manageable
        • Regulatory path clear
          • Timeline realistic with focused effort (3-4 years)
            • May require new partnerships
              • Selling price reasonable with scale

Examples:
  • Adapting AI technology from skincare to fragrance personalization
    • New sustainable ingredient requiring new supply chain
      • Connected device requiring IoT infrastructure


3 POINTS - MODERATELY FEASIBLE:
  • Technology emerging but not fully proven
    • Cost structure challenging but possible
      • Supply chain requires significant development
        • Regulatory uncertainty but likely approvable
          • Timeline aggressive (4-5 years)
            • Requires significant new capabilities
              • Selling price requires premium positioning

Examples:
  • Novel extraction technology (not yet scaled)
    • Biotech ingredients (R&D phase)
      • Complex phygital experience (multiple tech integrations)


2 POINTS - CHALLENGING FEASIBILITY:
  • Technology in early stages
    • Cost structure difficult to justify
      • Supply chain major challenge
        • Regulatory approval uncertain
          • Timeline unrealistic for competition timeframe
            • Requires capabilities L'Or√©al doesn't have


1 POINT - LOW FEASIBILITY:
  • Technology speculative
    • Cost prohibitive
      • Supply chain unclear
        • Regulatory blockers likely
          • Not achievable in foreseeable future


0 POINTS - NOT FEASIBLE:
  • Impossible with current technology
    • Economically unviable
      • Legally prohibited
        • Contradicts laws of physics/chemistry


Feasibility Sub-Criteria Breakdown:


A. TECHNICAL FEASIBILITY (Max 2 points):
  • Technology readiness (2 points: proven at scale, 1 point: prototype exists, 0 points: concept only)
    • L'Or√©al capabilities (1 point: internal capability, 0.5 point: partnership available, 0 points: no path)

B. ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY (Max 2 points):
  • Cost structure (1 point: profitable at proposed price, 0.5 point: needs scale, 0 points: uneconomic)
    • Investment required (1 point: low/medium, 0.5 point: high but justified, 0 points: prohibitive)

C. OPERATIONAL FEASIBILITY (Max 1 point):
  • Supply chain (0.5 point: existing or easy to build, 0 points: major challenge)
    • Regulatory (0.5 point: clear path, 0 points: uncertain/blocked)

Total Cap: 5 points maximum


CRITERION #5: SCALABLE (5 POINTS)


Official Definition:

"Present a project realizable on a big scale"


Scoring Rubric:


5 POINTS - GLOBALLY SCALABLE:
  • Easily adaptable across all geographies (US, Europe, China, emerging markets)
    • No cultural barriers to adoption
      • Technology/infrastructure scales linearly or better
        • Supply chain can support global demand
          • Regulatory approval achievable in all major markets
            • Business model works at 1M+ units
              • Digital components enable infinite scale
                • Franchise potential (apply to multiple brands)

Examples:
  • YSL Scent-Sation online version (digital = infinite scale)
    • Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ ingredients (can supply all L'Or√©al Luxe brands)
      • Refill fountain model (11,000+ Mugler fountains prove scale)

Questions:
  • Can this work in China, US, Europe, emerging markets?
    • Does scale improve economics (better with volume)?
      • Can infrastructure support 10X growth?
        • Is it franchise-able across L'Or√©al's 27 brands?


4 POINTS - HIGHLY SCALABLE:
  • Works in multiple regions (3+ of: NA, Europe, Asia, LATAM, MEA)
    • Minor adaptations needed for different markets
      • Technology/infrastructure scales well
        • Supply chain can support significant growth
          • Regulatory feasible in major markets
            • Business model works at 100K+ units
              • Could apply to multiple brands with adaptation

Examples:
  • Lanc√¥me Cell BioPrint launching China + Japan then global
    • Premium refillable bottles across portfolio
      • In-store personalization experiences


3 POINTS - MODERATELY SCALABLE:
  • Works in 2 major regions
    • Requires meaningful market adaptations
      • Technology scales but with investment
        • Supply chain needs development for scale
          • Regulatory varies by market
            • Business model profitable at 10K+ units
              • Limited to specific brands

Examples:
  • Cultural-specific aesthetic territories
    • Region-specific ingredient sourcing
      • High-touch in-store experiences (limited by physical retail)


2 POINTS - LIMITED SCALABILITY:
  • Works in 1 region only
    • Significant barriers to other markets
      • Technology hard to scale
        • Supply chain constrained
          • Regulatory approval limited geographies
            • Requires high unit economics (low volume)


1 POINT - MINIMAL SCALABILITY:
  • Pilot only
    • Cannot scale beyond test market
      • Prohibitive economics at scale


0 POINTS - NOT SCALABLE:
  • One-off project
    • Cannot be replicated


Scalability Sub-Criteria Breakdown:


A. GEOGRAPHIC SCALABILITY (Max 2 points):
  • Market reach (2 points: global, 1 point: multi-region, 0 points: single market)
    • Cultural adaptability (1 point: universal appeal or easy adaptation, 0 points: culture-specific)

B. OPERATIONAL SCALABILITY (Max 2 points):
  • Production scale (1 point: scales easily, 0.5 point: requires investment, 0 points: constrained)
    • Infrastructure scale (1 point: digital or network effects, 0.5 point: physical but expandable, 0 points: limited)

C. FRANCHISE SCALABILITY (Max 1 point):
  • Brand application (1 point: works across L'Or√©al Luxe portfolio, 0.5 point: limited to similar brands, 0 points: single brand only)

Total Cap: 5 points maximum


PROJECT EVALUATION SUMMARY SCORECARD:


Criterion Max Points Your Score Notes
**INNOVATIVE** 5 _____ Breakthrough? Unprecedented? Culture de l'√âcart?
**SUSTAINABLE** 5 _____ Circular? Regenerative? Industry-leading?
**INCLUSIVE** 5 _____ Multiple diversity dimensions? Barrier removal?
**FEASIBLE** 5 _____ Technology ready? Cost viable? L'Or√©al capability?
**SCALABLE** 5 _____ Global? Franchise-able? Network effects?
**TOTAL PROJECT** **25** **_____** **Minimum 20 recommended for finalist**


SECTION B: TEAM EVALUATION (25 POINTS)


Official Framework from Mission Document:


Teams evaluated on 5 criteria. Each criterion scored: 5 points (Strongly Observed), 2 points (Observed), or 0 points (Not Observed).



CRITERION #1: JUDGMENT (MAX 5 POINTS)


Official Question:

"What guided your decision-making in complex situations?"


Evaluation:


5 POINTS - STRONGLY OBSERVED:
  • Clear decision-making framework articulated
    • Evidence of considering multiple perspectives
      • Data-driven choices balanced with intuition
        • Demonstrates learning from past decisions
          • Strategic thinking (long-term implications considered)
            • Trade-offs explicitly acknowledged and reasoned
              • Could explain "why" behind every major choice

Examples of Strong Judgment:
  • "We chose Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ ingredients despite higher cost because proprietary advantage creates dupe immunity worth premium pricing"
    • "We targeted Experts first, then Newcomers (not both simultaneously) based on Exception study showing Expert abandonment when mass adopts"
      • "We planned 5-year re-enchantment despite commercial pressure to focus on launch, knowing lifecycle pattern shows 3-5 year pivot needed"


2 POINTS - OBSERVED:
  • Some decision-making rationale provided
    • Considered couple perspectives
      • Mix of data and gut feeling
        • Some learning from experience
          • Tactical thinking (immediate considerations)

Examples:
  • "We chose refillable packaging because it's sustainable"
    • "We decided on this price point because it's competitive"
      • "We picked this influencer because they're popular"


0 POINTS - NOT OBSERVED:
  • No rationale for decisions
    • Arbitrary choices
      • Ignored evidence
        • No learning demonstrated
          • Decisions contradict each other


Assessment Questions for Judges:


  • Did team explain WHY, not just WHAT they decided?
  • Were trade-offs acknowledged (not just benefits)?
  • Did they consider expert analysis in decision-making?
  • Can they articulate decision-making principles?
  • Did they learn and adjust from initial assumptions?


CRITERION #2: RESILIENCE (MAX 5 POINTS)


Official Question:

"What were the hurdles during the project and how did the team overcome them?"


Evaluation:


5 POINTS - STRONGLY OBSERVED:
  • Specific hurdles identified and overcome
    • Team shows adaptability and persistence
      • Creative problem-solving demonstrated
        • Turned obstacles into opportunities
          • Maintained morale and momentum
            • Learned and grew stronger from challenges
              • Evidence of iteration and improvement

Examples of Strong Resilience:
  • "Initial juice testing showed head notes copied easily by dupes. We pivoted to emphasize complex drydown architecture, turning weakness into competitive advantage"
    • "When cost analysis showed our tech infrastructure was too expensive, we redesigned for digital-first with physical overlay, reducing costs 60% while improving scalability"
      • "Our first narrative was marketing fiction. After Expert feedback, we rebuilt around authentic brand heritage, which was harder but created defensible positioning"


2 POINTS - OBSERVED:
  • Some challenges mentioned
    • Basic problem-solving
      • Kept going despite difficulties
        • Some adaptation

Examples:
  • "We faced timeline challenges but worked extra hours"
    • "Initial idea didn't work so we tried another approach"
      • "Team had disagreements but we resolved them"


0 POINTS - NOT OBSERVED:
  • No challenges mentioned (unrealistic)
    • Gave up when faced with obstacles
      • Blamed external factors
        • No adaptation or learning


Assessment Questions for Judges:


  • Were real, meaningful obstacles overcome (not trivial)?
  • Did team show creativity in problem-solving?
  • Did challenges improve the final project?
  • Was there evidence of iteration based on feedback?
  • Did team maintain positive attitude through difficulties?


CRITERION #3: AMBITION (MAX 5 POINTS)


Official Question:

"What were the vision and long-term goals of your project?"


Evaluation:


5 POINTS - STRONGLY OBSERVED:
  • Bold, transformative vision articulated
    • Long-term thinking (5-10 year horizon)
      • Industry-changing ambition
        • Not satisfied with incremental improvement
          • Vision beyond just winning competition
            • Strategic roadmap for scaling impact
              • Dream big but grounded in feasibility

Examples of Strong Ambition:
  • "Our vision is to make L'Or√©al the UNDUPABLE leader in Exception fragrance by layering proprietary tech, creating a moat competitors literally cannot cross"
    • "We aim to redefine luxury as 'made to last,' shifting entire industry from disposable opulence to permanent beauty, with L'Or√©al leading this paradigm shift"
      • "Long-term goal: Every L'Or√©al Luxe fragrance uses Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ ingredients within 5 years, creating portfolio-wide dupe immunity while preserving biodiversity"

Vision Components:
  • What does success look like in 5 years?
    • What industry norm do you want to change?
      • How does this scale beyond initial launch?
        • What's the ultimate impact?


2 POINTS - OBSERVED:
  • Some vision articulated
    • Thinks beyond immediate project
      • Wants to make positive impact
        • Moderately ambitious

Examples:
  • "We want to create a successful new fragrance"
    • "Goal is to capture Exception market growth"
      • "Vision is to be sustainable and profitable"


0 POINTS - NOT OBSERVED:
  • No vision beyond project itself
    • Only tactical thinking
      • No long-term goals
        • Risk-averse, unambitious


Assessment Questions for Judges:


  • Does vision inspire and excite?
  • Is there a 5-10 year roadmap?
  • Does team think about industry transformation (not just product launch)?
  • Is ambition balanced with feasibility?
  • Do they articulate impact beyond sales?


CRITERION #4: EMPATHY (MAX 5 POINTS)


Official Question:

"How do you support each other as a team?"


Evaluation:


5 POINTS - STRONGLY OBSERVED:
  • Clear evidence of mutual support
    • Psychological safety demonstrated
      • Celebrates each other's contributions
        • Recognizes different strengths
          • Handles disagreements constructively
            • Genuine care for team member well-being
              • Inclusive team dynamic (everyone's voice heard)

Examples of Strong Empathy:
  • "When [team member] was struggling with technical research, [other member] took over that workload so they could focus on their strength in narrative design"
    • "We had weekly check-ins not just on project but on each person's well-being, adjusting workload based on energy and capacity"
      • "Every major decision required consensus; we explicitly sought dissenting opinions to ensure all perspectives considered"
        • "We created space for [quieter team member] to contribute their ideas, which led to our breakthrough insight"


2 POINTS - OBSERVED:
  • Some mutual support
    • Team works together adequately
      • Generally respectful
        • Some collaboration

Examples:
  • "We divided work based on availability"
    • "We had regular team meetings"
      • "Everyone contributed to the project"


0 POINTS - NOT OBSERVED:
  • Dysfunctional team dynamic
    • No evidence of support
      • Individuals working in isolation
        • Conflicts unresolved


Assessment Questions for Judges:


  • Does team genuinely care about each other?
  • Are different strengths celebrated?
  • How do they handle disagreements?
  • Is there psychological safety?
  • Do ALL team members seem valued?


CRITERION #5: LEARNING AGILITY (MAX 5 POINTS)


Official Question:

"Did you encounter unfamiliar topics and how did you deal with it?"


Evaluation:


5 POINTS - STRONGLY OBSERVED:
  • Actively sought out new knowledge
    • Quickly mastered unfamiliar domains
      • Applied learnings to improve project
        • Sought expertise when needed
          • Demonstrated intellectual curiosity
            • Showed growth throughout project
              • Synthesized insights from multiple sources

Examples of Strong Learning Agility:
  • "None of us knew neuroscience, so we interviewed PhD researchers in olfactory perception, read 20+ papers, and within 2 weeks could discuss scent-emotion pathways credibly"
    • "We deep-dove into Exception study, Dupe analysis, CMI reports, synthesizing 200+ pages into actionable insights that shaped our entire strategy"
      • "When we discovered Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ technology, we researched extraction methods, visited (virtually) Grasse facilities, interviewed perfumers to understand how to leverage this for competitive advantage"

Learning Process:
  • What was unfamiliar at start?
    • How did you learn about it?
      • What sources did you use?
        • How did learning change your approach?
          • Can you demonstrate deep understanding now?


2 POINTS - OBSERVED:
  • Some learning demonstrated
    • Used available resources
      • Basic understanding acquired
        • Some adaptation based on learning

Examples:
  • "We researched fragrance market"
    • "We looked up sustainable ingredients"
      • "We learned about L'Or√©al brands"


0 POINTS - NOT OBSERVED:
  • No new learning
    • Stayed in comfort zone
      • Superficial understanding
        • Ignored unfamiliar areas


Assessment Questions for Judges:


  • What did team NOT know at start?
  • How deeply did they learn about it?
  • Can they demonstrate mastery now?
  • Did learning shape their innovation?
  • Did they seek expert input when needed?


TEAM EVALUATION SUMMARY SCORECARD:


Criterion Max Points Your Score Notes
**JUDGMENT** 5 _____ Decision framework? Trade-offs considered? Strategic thinking?
**RESILIENCE** 5 _____ Obstacles overcome? Creative problem-solving? Iteration?
**AMBITION** 5 _____ Transformative vision? Long-term roadmap? Industry impact?
**EMPATHY** 5 _____ Mutual support? Psychological safety? All voices heard?
**LEARNING AGILITY** 5 _____ New domains mastered? Expert input sought? Growth shown?
**TOTAL TEAM** **25** **_____** **Minimum 20 recommended for finalist**


OFFICIAL BRANDSTORM SCORE (TIER 1 TOTAL):


Category Max Points Your Score
**PROJECT EVALUATION** 25 _____
**TEAM EVALUATION** 25 _____
**GRAND TOTAL (OFFICIAL)** **50** **_____**

OFFICIAL PASSING THRESHOLDS:
  • 45-50 points: EXCEPTIONAL - Strong Finalist/Winner Potential
    • 40-44 points: EXCELLENT - Finalist Potential
      • 35-39 points: STRONG - Competitive Entry
        • 30-34 points: ADEQUATE - Needs Improvement
          • Below 30: WEAK - Significant Gaps


TIER 2: L'OR√âAL SUCCESS PATTERN ALIGNMENT


Strategic Assessment Beyond Official Criteria (100 POINTS)


This tier evaluates alignment with L'Or√©al's proven success patterns identified in our deep analysis. While not official competition criteria, these predict real-world market success.



DIMENSION 1: FOUNDATIONAL VALUES ALIGNMENT (20 POINTS)


Evaluates how well innovation embodies L'Or√©al Luxe's 5 core values.


A. CULTURE DE L'√âCART - THE TWIST (5 points)


5 points: Embodies "twist culture" perfectly - seeks what's never been done, pushes boundaries, creates the "√©cart" (gap) between L'Or√©al and competition

3 points: Shows some twist/disruption but not fundamental reimagination

1 point: Incremental, no real "√©cart"

0 points: Follows conventional path


Assessment Question: Does this make you say "Only L'Or√©al Luxe could do this"?



B. ART & SCIENCE FUSION (4 points)


4 points: Masterful balance - artistic vision + scientific rigor, neither dominates

2 points: Leans art OR science, other dimension weak

0 points: Art alone (beautiful but unscalable) OR science alone (functional but soulless)


Assessment Question: Would this impress both perfumers (art) AND scientists (tech)?



C. INCLUSIVITY & ACCESSIBILITY (4 points)


4 points: Designed FOR diversity, removes barriers others don't address

2 points: Doesn't exclude but doesn't actively include

0 points: Exclusive or ignores accessibility


Assessment Question: Who is STILL excluded by current solutions that this includes?



D. SUSTAINABILITY & RESPONSIBILITY (4 points)


4 points: Regenerative (improves environment), circular economy model

2 points: Reduced harm, recyclable elements

0 points: Standard disposable model


Assessment Question: Would CDP Triple A and EcoVadis Platinum recognize this?



E. FRENCH HERITAGE + GLOBAL REACH (3 points)


3 points: Authentically French (craft, perfume heritage) yet globally scalable

2 points: Generic luxury OR culturally specific without scale

1 point: Neither authentically rooted nor scalable

0 points: Contradicts heritage or impossible to scale


Assessment Question: Does this honor 60 years L'Or√©al fragrance expertise while reaching global markets?



DIMENSION 2: GUIDING IDEOLOGIES ADHERENCE (30 POINTS)


Evaluates how well innovation follows L'Or√©al's 8 strategic belief systems.


A. TIME AS STRATEGIC ASSET (4 points)


4 points: Long-term build (3-7 year roadmap), resists short-term pressure, plans re-enchantment

2 points: Some long-term thinking but vulnerable to quarterly thinking

0 points: Shooting star approach, chasing immediate viral moment


Assessment: Is there a 5-year evolution roadmap?



B. VIRALITY AMPLIFIES, DOESN'T CREATE (4 points)


4 points: Builds exceptional foundation FIRST, then activates virality strategically (must-haves ‚Üí contributors ‚Üí boosters)

2 points: Some foundation but leads with virality

0 points: Virality-first without substance (Gris Dior mistake)


Assessment: If TikTok disappeared tomorrow, would this still succeed?



C. EXPERTS VALIDATE, NEWCOMERS SCALE (4 points)


4 points: Clear Expert ‚Üí Newcomer progression, maintains both

2 points: Serves one target well, other poorly

0 points: Ignores dual target dynamic


Assessment: Would Expert communities validate this? Would Newcomers amplify it?



D. UNDUPABLE BY DESIGN (5 points)


5 points: Layers multiple undupable elements (proprietary tech + heritage + infrastructure + personalization + ecosystem)

3 points: Some undupable elements but dupes could replicate core

1 point: Token barriers, easily copied

0 points: Dupe-bait (will be copied immediately)


Assessment: How many layers would dupes need to copy? Can they access proprietary tech?



E. TECH ENHANCES, NEVER REPLACES (3 points)


3 points: Technology augments human artistry, "invisible magic"

2 points: Tech present but clunky or overwhelming

0 points: Tech replaces craft OR no tech integration


Assessment: Does tech make perfumer/experience better (not obsolete)?



F. SUSTAINABILITY = LUXURY (3 points)


3 points: Sustainability IS the luxury story (made to last, refillable ritual)

2 points: Sustainability add-on (not core to luxury positioning)

0 points: Sustainability compromises luxury OR greenwashing


Assessment: Is "made to last" positioned as ultimate luxury?



G. NARRATIVE AUTHENTICITY (4 points)


4 points: Story rooted in real brand heritage, provable, expert-credible

2 points: Some authentic elements mixed with marketing fiction

0 points: Fabricated story, dupes could claim same narrative


Assessment: Can this story be verified? Is it ownable by L'Or√©al only?



H. NO ONE-SIZE-FITS-ALL (3 points)


3 points: Embraces unique approach, doesn't copy formulas, authentic to THIS brand

2 points: Some uniqueness but follows established patterns

0 points: "Our Baccarat Rouge 540" copycat approach


Assessment: Is this attempting to replicate another success or create new magic?



DIMENSION 3: SUCCESS PATTERNS INTEGRATION (50 POINTS)


Evaluates implementation of L'Or√©al's 12 proven success patterns.


PATTERN 1: EXCEPTIONAL JUICE FOUNDATION (8 points)

8 points:
  • Immediate olfactory message: clear, simple (2 pts)
    • Olfactive incident: strong partis pris creating signature (2 pts)
      • Complex architecture: drydown reveals over time (2 pts)
        • Proprietary ingredients: Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ or equivalent (2 pts)

Assessment: Would perfumers recognize this as exceptional? Is juice the non-negotiable foundation?



PATTERN 2: LONG-TERM BUILD (4 points)

4 points: 3-7 year roadmap with re-enchantment plan

2 points: Some long-term thinking

0 points: Launch-and-pray approach



PATTERN 3: DUAL TARGET BALANCE (4 points)

4 points: Expert discovery ‚Üí validation ‚Üí Newcomer activation ‚Üí scale management with retention strategies

2 points: Addresses both but no progression plan

0 points: Single target focus



PATTERN 4: PROPRIETARY ADVANTAGE (6 points)

6 points: Leverages Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ (2) + Beauty Tech (2) + Couture brands (1) + Refill infrastructure (1) = multiple proprietary layers

3 points: Some proprietary elements

0 points: No defensible advantage



PATTERN 5: SOPHISTICATED NARRATIVE (4 points)

4 points: Identity + aesthetics blend, culturally rooted, conceptual depth

2 points: Basic narrative

0 points: No narrative or surface-level



PATTERN 6: STRATEGIC VIRALITY (4 points)

4 points: All must-haves (scent profile 29% + aesthetic territory 24%), strong contributors, strategic celebrity boosters

2 points: Some viral elements

0 points: Virality ignored or misunderstood



PATTERN 7: REFILLABILITY (4 points)

4 points: Refillable by design, infrastructure plan, "made to last" luxury positioning

2 points: Refillable bottle but no system

0 points: Disposable



PATTERN 8: PERSONALIZATION AT SCALE (4 points)

4 points: Beauty Tech enables individual relationships (AI, neuroscience, data-driven), scales infinitely

2 points: Basic personalization

0 points: One-size-fits-all



PATTERN 9: OMNICHANNEL EXCELLENCE (4 points)

4 points: Seamless online discovery + offline ritual + ecosystem integration

2 points: Online OR offline well, not integrated

0 points: Single channel



PATTERN 10: COUTURE TRANSLATION (4 points)

4 points: Authentically translates fashion house DNA to fragrance, leverages couture partnership

2 points: Generic luxury not specific to brand

0 points: Ignores brand heritage

N/A: If not using couture brand, score based on brand heritage utilization



PATTERN 11: SAFETY/ETHICS/EDUCATION (2 points)

2 points: Proactively educates on safety/ethics as differentiation from dupes

1 point: Mentions safety/ethics

0 points: Ignores or greenwashes



PATTERN 12: RE-ENCHANTMENT PLANNING (2 points)

2 points: 5-year re-enchantment strategy to avoid red ocean

1 point: Aware of lifecycle but no plan

0 points: No consideration of post-launch evolution



TIER 2 SUMMARY SCORECARD:


Dimension Max Points Your Score Notes
**Foundational Values Alignment** 20 _____ Culture de l'√âcart? Art & Science? Inclusivity? Sustainability? Heritage + Reach?
**Guiding Ideologies Adherence** 30 _____ Time? Virality? Dual Target? Undupable? Tech Enhances? Sustainability=Luxury? Authenticity? Unique Magic?
**Success Patterns Integration** 50 _____ All 12 patterns considered and implemented?
**TIER 2 TOTAL** **100** **_____** **Minimum 75 recommended for real-world success**


TIER 3: EXCEPTION MARKET POTENTIAL


Market Fit Assessment (50 POINTS)


This tier evaluates potential to capture Exception fragrance Eldorado (‚Ç¨7.5B market, +29% growth).



DIMENSION 1: EXCEPTION CONTRACT FULFILLMENT (20 POINTS)


Does innovation meet Exception market requirements?


A. JUICE AS ENTRY POINT (8 points)


  • Top-level technique (3 points): Expert-recognized mastery
  • Olfactive incident (3 points): Memorable signature, polarizing boldness
  • Immediate message (2 points): Simple, qualitative communication

Assessment: Would this be discussed in fragrance expert forums? Would it be recognizable in blind test?



B. SOPHISTICATED NARRATIVE (6 points)


  • Imaginaire depth (3 points): Beyond archetyped incarnation to broader desire
  • Identity + aesthetics (3 points): Blend both dimensions

Assessment: "Exception is to fragrance what couture is to fashion" - does this meet that standard?



C. ELEVATED PRICING (3 points)


3 points: ‚Ç¨150-250 range (Exception sweet spot)

2 points: ‚Ç¨100-150 (Premium but not Exception)

1 point: ‚Ç¨50-100 (Prestige)

0 points: Below ‚Ç¨50 (Access)


Assessment: Does pricing signal Exception positioning? Can value justify premium?



D. TIME FOR MAGIC (3 points)


3 points: Designed for 3-7 year endurance, not shooting star

2 points: Some long-term thinking

0 points: Viral moment approach



DIMENSION 2: TARGET AUDIENCE APPEAL (15 POINTS)


Does it attract dual target (Experts + Newcomers)?


A. EXPERT VALIDATION POTENTIAL (8 points)


Experts seek: Confidentiality (2), Avant-garde scent (2), Technique (2), Olfactory surprise (1), Originality (1)


8 points: Would be featured on Fragrantica, Basenotes; experts would champion as "hidden treasure"

4 points: Experts would respect but not champion

0 points: Experts would dismiss as mainstream/boring


Assessment: Would @perfumerism (558K followers) make content about this? Would Jeremy Fragrance review positively?



B. NEWCOMER ADOPTION POTENTIAL (7 points)


Newcomers seek: Status (2), Compliments (2), Buzzy/viral (2), Fashion item (1)


7 points: "IT girl" potential, #fragrancetok viral, status symbol

4 points: Some appeal but not buzzy

0 points: No newcomer hooks


Assessment: Would @paulireactss (2.1M followers) feature this? Would it trend on #fragrancetok?



DIMENSION 3: ELEVATION PATHWAYS (10 POINTS)


Does it enable consumer elevation (Exception core motivation)?


A. UNIQUENESS (4 points - France-led)


4 points: Confidential, refined, wearing something unique

2 points: Some uniqueness

0 points: Generic


Assessment: Does this give wearer "I have something special" feeling?



B. COMPLIMENTS (3 points - USA-led)


3 points: Compliment-getter scent, strong projection, seduction power

2 points: Pleasant but not memorable

0 points: Doesn't project or stand out


Assessment: Would strangers ask "What perfume are you wearing?"



C. STATUS (3 points - USA + China)


3 points: Signals education, knowledge, social achievement, "smell rich"

2 points: Some status signal

0 points: No status connotation


Assessment: Does wearing this communicate sophistication, taste, cultural capital?



DIMENSION 4: GEOGRAPHY POTENTIAL (5 POINTS)


Where will this succeed?


France (1 point): Uniqueness-driven, high sustainability concern, expert-heavy

USA (2 points): Compliments + status, largest Exception market (26% SOM)

China (1 point): Status-driven, education signal, Gen Z Exception adoption (17% vs 10% US)

Travel Retail (1 point): +67% growth, experience-driven


5 points: Strong in 4 geographies

3 points: Strong in 2-3

1 point: Strong in 1 only


Assessment: Does this adapt to different elevation pathways per geography?



TIER 3 SUMMARY SCORECARD:


Dimension Max Points Your Score Notes
**Exception Contract Fulfillment** 20 _____ Juice quality? Narrative depth? Pricing? Time horizon?
**Target Audience Appeal** 15 _____ Expert validation? Newcomer adoption?
**Elevation Pathways** 10 _____ Uniqueness? Compliments? Status?

TIER 4: DUPE IMMUNITY & DEFENSIBILITY


Competitive Moat Assessment (50 POINTS)


This tier evaluates resistance to dupe commoditization (+49% YoY threat).



DIMENSION 1: UNDUPABLE LAYERS (25 POINTS)


How many barriers must dupes cross?


LAYER 1: PROPRIETARY INGREDIENTS (5 points)

5 points: Osmobloom‚Ñ¢ or equivalent exclusive tech (literally impossible to dupe)

3 points: Rare/expensive ingredients (possible but costly to dupe)

1 point: Premium but available ingredients

0 points: Common ingredients


Assessment: Can Zara, Lattafa, Dossier access these ingredients?



LAYER 2: COMPLEX OLFACTIVE ARCHITECTURE (5 points)

5 points: Deconstructed pyramid, drydown magic, multi-layered (head notes copyable but heart/base undupable)

3 points: Some complexity

1 point: Simple structure

0 points: Linear scent (easy to copy)


Assessment: Consumer quote: "Dupes clone head notes but disappoint in lastingness" - does this exploit that gap?



LAYER 3: BRAND LEGITIMACY (4 points)

4 points: Authentic heritage (60 years, French Grasse, UNESCO), couture partnership

2 points: Some brand story

0 points: New brand or generic


Assessment: Can dupes claim same heritage with credibility?



LAYER 4: PREMIUM CRAFTSMANSHIP (3 points)

3 points: Heavy materials, perfect execution, luxury feel, refillable infrastructure

2 points: Nice packaging

0 points: Standard bottle


Assessment: At dupe price ($20-35), can they match this quality?



LAYER 5: PERSONALIZED EXPERIENCE (4 points)

4 points: AI/neuroscience personalization creating individual relationship

2 points: Basic personalization (quiz)

0 points: One-size-fits-all


Assessment: Do dupes offer Scent-Sation equivalent?



LAYER 6: CONNECTED ECOSYSTEM (4 points)

4 points: Refill fountains, omnichannel, community, smart devices

2 points: Some ecosystem elements

0 points: Single product transaction


Assessment: Is this a system dupes cannot replicate?



DIMENSION 2: DUPE STUDY RECOMMENDATIONS (15 POINTS)


Implements 6 strategic recommendations from Dupe Analysis?


A. Highlight Brand DNA/Status/Legitimacy (3 points)


3 points: Story rooted in origins, heritage, values; showcases why concepts linked to brand; emotional connection

1 point: Generic brand story

0 points: No brand narrative



B. Express Olfactive Expertise (3 points)


3 points: Ingredients quality story, olfactive family, pyramid, perfumer signature, confidential formula

1 point: Mentions perfumer

0 points: No expertise communication



C. Support Longlasting Claims (3 points)


3 points: Drydown beauty + sillage (#BEASTMODE), rational explanation (raw materials, extraction, balanced composition)

1 point: Claims longlasting

0 points: No performance story



D. Highlight Quality & Craftsmanship (2 points)


2 points: Unique craftsmanship story, quality execution, behind-the-scenes content

1 point: Mentions quality

0 points: No craft story



E. Difficult to Copy Design (2 points)


2 points: Limited editions, artist co-creation, preempt unique ingredients, collector positioning

1 point: Some scarcity

0 points: Mass production



F. Educate on Safety & Ethics (2 points)


2 points: Proactive safety/ethics education, lab tests, sourcing traceability, fair remuneration, industry efforts

1 point: Mentions safety

0 points: No education strategy



DIMENSION 3: DUPE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT (10 POINTS)


What CAN dupes copy?


Risk Assessment:

10 points - LOW VULNERABILITY:
  • Dupes could copy scent profile (head notes) but not drydown
    • Could copy aesthetic but not brand legitimacy
      • Could copy concept but not heritage authenticity
        • Could copy packaging look but not quality feel
          • Could NOT copy: Proprietary tech, personalization, infrastructure
            • 6+ undupable layers protecting innovation


6 points - MEDIUM VULNERABILITY:
  • Dupes could copy most elements with effort
    • 3-5 undupable layers
      • Some proprietary elements but core replicable


3 points - HIGH VULNERABILITY:
  • Dupes could easily replicate core value
    • 1-2 undupable layers only
      • Mostly common ingredients/tech


0 points - EXTREME VULNERABILITY:
  • Dupe-bait: Will be copied immediately and comprehensively
    • Zero undupable layers
      • Zara could launch copycat within 6 months


Assessment Questions:
  • How long until first dupe appears? (More time = better)
    • What % of value proposition can dupes replicate? (Less = better)
      • At what cost could dupes copy this? (Higher cost = better for us)
        • Would dupe consumers still prefer original? (Yes = good)


TIER 4 SUMMARY SCORECARD:


Dimension Max Points Your Score Notes
**Undupable Layers** 25 _____ 6 layers: Proprietary ingredients? Complex architecture? Brand legitimacy? Craftsmanship? Personalization? Ecosystem?
**Dupe Study Recommendations** 15 _____ Implements all 6 strategic defenses?
**Dupe Vulnerability** 10 _____ How easily/quickly can dupes copy? What % of value is undupable?
**TIER 4 TOTAL** **50** **_____** **Minimum 35 for dupe resistance**


COMPREHENSIVE SCORING SUMMARY


ALL TIERS INTEGRATED:


Tier Category Max Points Your Score Percentage
**TIER 1** Official Competition Criteria 50 _____ _____%
- Project Evaluation (25) _____
- Team Evaluation (25) _____
**TIER 2** L'Or√©al Success Pattern Alignment 100 _____ _____%
- Foundational Values (20) _____
- Guiding Ideologies (30) _____
- Success Patterns (50) _____
**TIER 3** Exception Market Potential 50 _____ _____%
- Exception Contract (20) _____
- Target Audience Appeal (15) _____
- Elevation Pathways (10) _____
- Geography Potential (5) _____
**TIER 4** Dupe Immunity & Defensibility 50 _____ _____%
- Undupable Layers (25) _____
- Dupe Recommendations (15) _____
- Vulnerability Assessment (10) _____
**GRAND TOTAL** **ALL TIERS** **250** **_____** **_____**%


INTERPRETATION GUIDE:


TIER 1 (Official - 50 points):


  • 45-50: EXCEPTIONAL - Strong Finalist/Winner
  • 40-44: EXCELLENT - Finalist Potential
  • 35-39: STRONG - Competitive
  • 30-34: ADEQUATE - Needs Work
  • Below 30: WEAK - Major Gaps

TIER 2 (Success Patterns - 100 points):


  • 85-100: ALIGNED - Embodies L'Or√©al DNA
  • 70-84: STRONG - Good alignment
  • 50-69: MODERATE - Some gaps
  • Below 50: MISALIGNED - Contradicts values

TIER 3 (Exception Market - 50 points):


  • 40-50: EXCEPTION LEADER - Perfect fit
  • 30-39: EXCEPTION PLAYER - Good potential
  • 20-29: PRESTIGE - Wrong segment
  • Below 20: ACCESS - Mispositioned

TIER 4 (Dupe Immunity - 50 points):


  • 40-50: FORTRESS - Undupable
  • 30-39: DEFENDED - Strong moat
  • 20-29: VULNERABLE - Some protection
  • Below 20: DUPE-BAIT - Will be copied


WINNING PROFILES:


PROFILE A: THE EXCEPTIONAL WINNER (200-250 total)


  • Tier 1: 40-50 (Official criteria strong)
  • Tier 2: 85-100 (Perfect L'Or√©al alignment)
  • Tier 3: 40-50 (Exception market fit)
  • Tier 4: 35-50 (Highly defensible)

Characteristics:** Breakthrough innovation embodying Culture de l'√âcart, positioned for Exception Eldorado, immune to dupes, executes perfectly on all Brandstorm criteria. **FINALIST + REAL-WORLD SUCCESS POTENTIAL.


PROFILE B: THE STRONG CONTENDER (175-199 total)


  • Tier 1: 35-44 (Solid on official criteria)
  • Tier 2: 70-84 (Good L'Or√©al fit)
  • Tier 3: 30-45 (Strong market potential)
  • Tier 4: 25-35 (Defensible)

Characteristics:** Strong innovation with minor gaps. Good execution. **POSSIBLE FINALIST, NEEDS REFINEMENT.


PROFILE C: THE PROMISING IDEA (150-174 total)


  • Tier 1: 30-39 (Meets basics)
  • Tier 2: 50-69 (Partial alignment)
  • Tier 3: 25-35 (Market fit uncertain)
  • Tier 4: 20-30 (Moderate defense)

Characteristics:** Good foundation but needs significant development. Strategic gaps. **COMPETITIVE ENTRY, MAJOR IMPROVEMENTS NEEDED.


PROFILE D: THE RISKY BET (125-149 total)


  • Uneven scores across tiers
  • May excel in one tier but fail others

Examples:
  • High Tier 1 (official criteria) but Low Tier 4 (dupe-bait)
    • High Tier 2 (L'Or√©al fit) but Low Tier 1 (execution flaws)
      • High Tier 3 (market potential) but Low Tier 2 (contradicts values)

Characteristics:** Might win competition but fail in market OR vice versa. **STRATEGIC MISALIGNMENT.


PROFILE E: THE UNDERCOOKED CONCEPT (Below 125 total)


  • Multiple significant gaps
  • Not ready for competition

Characteristics:** Needs fundamental rework. **MAJOR REVISION REQUIRED.


USAGE GUIDELINES:


FOR TEAMS SELF-EVALUATING:


  • Score honestly - inflated scores hurt your development
  • Identify gaps early - iterate before submission
  • Focus on Tier 2 - L'Or√©al alignment often overlooked but critical
  • Don't ignore Tier 4 - dupe immunity is competitive advantage
  • Balance tiers - aim for 80%+ across ALL tiers (not just Tier 1)

    • FOR JUDGES EVALUATING:


  • Start with Tier 1 (official criteria) - must meet competition standards
  • Then assess Tier 2 - L'Or√©al DNA fit predicts internal support
  • Evaluate Tier 3 - market potential predicts real-world success
  • Finally Tier 4 - defensibility predicts longevity

    • WINNING INNOVATIONS: Strong across ALL FOUR TIERS (not just high Tier 1).


    FOR STRATEGIC DECISIONS:


    If choosing between two projects:
    • Project A: Tier 1: 45, Tier 2: 60, Tier 3: 35, Tier 4: 25 = 165 total
      • Project B: Tier 1: 40, Tier 2: 85, Tier 3: 42, Tier 4: 38 = 205 total

    Choose Project B: Lower official score but MUCH stronger L'Or√©al alignment, market fit, and defensibility. More likely to win AND succeed in market.



    CONCLUSION:


    This four-tier framework evaluates innovations holistically:


    TIER 1: Can it win Brandstorm? (Official criteria)

    TIER 2: Does it embody L'Or√©al DNA? (Internal fit)

    TIER 3: Will it capture Exception growth? (Market opportunity)

    TIER 4: Can it resist dupes? (Competitive defense)


    IDEAL INNOVATION: Scores 200+ total with strength across all tiers.


    TARGET: 80% or higher in each tier individually = balanced excellence.



    Next Step: Use this framework to evaluate and refine your Brandstorm 2026 innovation until it achieves 200+ total score with no tier below 60%.



    Document Classification: Strategic Assessment Framework - Internal Use

    Preparation Date: January 2026

    Purpose: Comprehensive evaluation system for Brandstorm 2026 innovations

    Version: 2.0 (Enhanced Multi-Tier)


    BRANDSTORM 2026 WINNING PROJECT BLUEPRINT

    Strategic Roadmap for Creating Undupable Luxury Fragrance Innovation


    Document Version: 1.0 (Master Blueprint)

    Preparation Date: January 2026

    Purpose: Comprehensive actionable framework for developing winning Brandstorm 2026 innovations

    Target Audience: Competition teams seeking systematic approach to innovation excellence



    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


    This blueprint synthesizes insights from:

    • L'Or√©al Brandstorm 2026 Mission Document
    • Exception Fragrance Market Analysis (‚Ç¨7.5B, +29% growth)
    • CMI Dupes in Fragrance Study (+49% YoY threat)
    • L'Or√©al's 60 years of success patterns
    • Cross-reference strategic analysis

    The Winning Formula:

    `

    EXCEPTIONAL JUICE (proprietary, olfactive incident, complex drydown)

    √ó

    SOPHISTICATED NARRATIVE (authentic heritage, identity + aesthetics)

    √ó

    PREMIUM CRAFTSMANSHIP (made to last, refillable, sensory excellence)

    √ó

    INVISIBLE TECH (AI personalization, connected ecosystems)

    √ó

    STRATEGIC TIME (expert validation ‚Üí newcomer scale)

    √ó

    CULTURE DE L'√âCART (signature twist, boundary-pushing)

    =

    UNDUPABLE LUXURY CAPTURING EXCEPTION ELDORADO

    `


    Blueprint Structure:
    • PHASE 1: Foundation (Weeks 1-3) - Research, insights, strategic positioning
      • PHASE 2: Ideation (Weeks 4-5) - Concept development, feasibility
        • PHASE 3: Refinement (Weeks 6-8) - Prototyping, validation, iteration
          • PHASE 4: Execution (Weeks 9-10) - Pitch creation, team preparation
            • PHASE 5: Delivery (Week 11-12) - Submission, presentation excellence


    PHASE 1: FOUNDATION (WEEKS 1-3)


    The Strategic Discovery Phase


    Objective: Build deep understanding before ideating. Rush to solutions = mediocre innovations.



    WEEK 1: IMMERSION & ANALYSIS


    DAY 1-2: DIGEST ALL MATERIALS


    Required Reading (Priority Order):

  • Brandstorm 2026 Mission Document (1-2 hours)
    • Focus: Playing fields, evaluation criteria, deliverables
    • Extract: What does L'Or√©al explicitly want?
    • Note: Official constraints (3 slides, 3 minutes, brand scope)

  • Exception Fragrance Executive Summary (2-3 hours)
    • Focus: The Eldorado opportunity, success patterns, lifecycle
    • Extract: What makes Exception successful?
    • Note: Dual target (Experts + Newcomers), virality framework

  • CMI Dupes in Fragrance Study (2-3 hours)
    • Focus: The dupe threat, consumer profiles, L'Or√©al products at risk
    • Extract: What makes innovations undupable?
    • Note: 6 layers of defense, strategic recommendations

  • Cross-Reference Analysis (2 hours)
    • Focus: 7 strategic themes connecting all materials
    • Extract: The strategic paradox (opportunity vs threat)
    • Note: Innovation spaces identified

  • L'Or√©al Values & Success Patterns (2 hours)
    • Focus: 5 values, 8 ideologies, 12 success patterns
    • Extract: What does L'Or√©al DNA demand?
    • Note: Culture de l'√âcart embodiment

    Deliverable: Team synthesis document (5-10 pages) answering:

    • What is the core challenge?
    • What does success look like?
    • What are the constraints?
    • What are our strategic advantages?


    DAY 3-4: MARKET & CONSUMER DEEP DIVE


    Consumer Understanding:

    EXERCISE 1: DUAL TARGET PERSONAS

    Create detailed personas for BOTH targets:


    EXPERT PERSONA ("The Connoisseur"):
    • Demographics: Age, gender, location
      • Psychographics: Values, lifestyle, taste
        • Fragrance behavior: Collection size, spending, discovery process
          • Elevation path: UNIQUENESS (confidentiality, avant-garde, technique)
            • Pain points: Mass adoption kills appeal, hard to find truly unique
              • Dream state: "Hidden treasure" only experts know
                • Where they discover: Fragrantica, Basenotes, niche boutiques, expert influencers

    NEWCOMER PERSONA ("The Aspirant"):
    • Demographics: Gen Z to Millennial, social media native
      • Psychographics: Trend-conscious, status-seeking, fashion-forward
        • Fragrance behavior: Fewer bottles, higher spend per, influenced by TikTok
          • Elevation path: COMPLIMENTS (USA) or STATUS (China)
            • Pain points: Can't afford all the perfumes they want, FOMO on trends
              • Dream state: Be "that girl" everyone asks about scent
                • Where they discover: #fragrancetok, Instagram, celebrity/influencer recommendations

    EXERCISE 2: CONSUMER JOURNEY MAPPING

    Map BOTH journeys:


    Expert Journey:

    1. Discovery (niche boutique, expert forum, "underground" buzz)

    2. Research (olfactive notes, perfumer story, brand heritage)

    3. Test (in-store skin test, drydown evaluation over hours)

    4. Validation (check expert community opinions)

    5. Purchase (invest in full bottle, proud of find)

    6. Advocacy (share in expert communities, "hidden treasure")

    7. Collection (display, rotation, layering experimentation)


    Newcomer Journey:

    1. Discovery (TikTok video, influencer post, celebrity mention)

    2. Desire (FOMO, want to be part of trend)

    3. Research (quick search, dupes check, price comparison)

    4. Test (sample if available, or blind buy based on trust)

    5. Purchase (gift to self or receive as gift)

    6. Social proof (unboxing, "GRWM", compliment-getting stories)

    7. Repurchase OR move to next trend



    DAY 5-7: COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE MAPPING


    EXERCISE 3: EXCEPTION MARKET POSITIONING

    Create visual map with axes:

    • Horizontal: ORIGINALITY ‚Üê ‚Üí STATUS
    • Vertical: OLFACTIVE EXPERTISE ‚Üë ‚Üì DOMINANT NARRATIVES

    Plot brands:

    • Niche Pure Players: Le Labo, Byredo, MFK, Diptyque (ORIGINALITY + varied)
    • Couture Collections: Tom Ford, Dior, Armani Priv√© (STATUS + EXPERTISE)
    • L'Or√©al Luxe: Where do our brands sit? Where are white spaces?

    White Space Questions:
    • Where is NO ONE playing?
      • Where is everyone crowded (red ocean)?
        • Where can L'Or√©al uniquely win (proprietary advantage)?

    EXERCISE 4: DUPE THREAT ANALYSIS

    For L'Or√©al's bestsellers, analyze:


    Product Dupe Growth What Dupes Copy What They Can't Copy
    Libre -17% YoY Lavender scent, golden aesthetic Complex drydown, freedom narrative authenticity, YSL heritage
    Born in Roma Donna +54% YoY ‚ö†Ô∏è Sweet scent, pink aesthetic, "IT girl" Valentino couture connection, packaging quality, longevity
    Stronger With You +50% YoY ‚ö†Ô∏è Warm cozy scent, autumnal vibe Intensity, Armani sophistication, curvy bottle quality

    Strategic Insight: Growing dupe conversations = product success signal. Use this to identify what's working, then LAYER undupable elements.



    WEEK 2: STRATEGIC POSITIONING


    DAY 8-9: BRAND SCOPE DECISION


    Critical Choice #1: Which L'Or√©al Entity?

    Option A: L'Or√©al Groupe (All Divisions)
    • Advantage: Largest scale, franchise across all brands
      • Challenge: Hard to be specific, generic solutions
        • Best For: Tech infrastructure, sustainability systems, platforms

    Option B: L'Or√©al Luxe Division
    • Advantage: Exception positioning, premium justification, 27 brands
      • Challenge: Still broad, need strong concept
        • Best For: Refill systems, omnichannel experiences, portfolio innovations

    Option C: Specific L'Or√©al Luxe Brand (YSL, Lanc√¥me, Prada, Valentino, Armani, MM)
    • Advantage: Leverage specific brand DNA, authentic narrative, clear target
      • Challenge: Limited scale demonstration
        • Best For: New fragrance launches, brand-specific experiences

    RECOMMENDATION: Choose Option C (Specific Brand) for strongest pitch


    Why:

    1. Authenticity: Real brand heritage = sophisticated narrative

    2. Credibility: Can deeply understand brand DNA

    3. Specificity: Clearer vision, easier to visualize

    4. Jury Appeal: More concrete than generic "for all brands"


    Then demonstrate: "This innovation STARTS with [Brand] but is FRANCHISE-ABLE across L'Or√©al Luxe portfolio" (shows scale thinking)



    EXERCISE 5: BRAND DNA EXTRACTION

    If choosing specific brand (recommended), extract its DNA:


    YSL BEAUTY EXAMPLE:

    HERITAGE:
    • Yves Saint Laurent: First designer to democratize luxury, Le Smoking tuxedo for women
      • Rock, cutting-edge energy
        • Paris, nightlife, freedom, rebellion

    OLFACTIVE SIGNATURE:
    • Libre: Lavender foug√®re (masculine structure, feminine expression)
      • Opium: Oriental boldness
        • M7: Oud pioneer in Western market

    VISUAL CODES:
    • Black, gold, sleek lines
      • YSL monogram
        • Sexy confidence

    NARRATIVE TERRITORIES:
    • Freedom, liberation ("Libre" = Free)
      • Rock chic, edgy elegance
        • Parisian nights, living by own rules

    TARGET:
    • Empowered women
      • Confident, rule-breakers
        • Gen Z + Millennials
          • Status + Compliments elevation

    TECH INTEGRATION:
    • Scent-Sation (neuroscience + AI)
      • Hyper Look Studio (AR + generative AI)
        • Beauty Tech pioneer

    OPPORTUNITY SPACE FOR YSL:

    What innovation would feel AUTHENTICALLY YSL while being UNPRECEDENTED?


    (Repeat this exercise for whichever brand you choose)



    DAY 10-12: PLAYING FIELD SELECTION


    Critical Choice #2: Which Playing Fields?

    Mission Document offers 4 playing fields:

  • Product Craftsmanship
  • Tech & Science
  • Transformative Experience
  • Advocacy & Communities

    • RECOMMENDATION: Choose 2-3 playing fields (not all 4)


    Why:
    • Depth > Breadth
      • Integration creates uniqueness
        • "Culture de l'√âcart" is often at INTERSECTION of fields

    WINNING COMBINATIONS:

    COMBO A: Product Craftsmanship + Tech & Science
    • Strength: Proprietary advantage (Osmobloom‚Ñ¢), undupable layers
      • Example: New fragrance using AI-discovered accord + exclusive extraction
        • Best For: Juice innovation, ingredient stories, technical credibility

    COMBO B: Tech & Science + Transformative Experience
    • Strength: Personalization at scale, ecosystem creation
      • Example: AI olfactory profiling + phygital discovery journey
        • Best For: Experience innovation, omnichannel, newcomer appeal

    COMBO C: Product Craftsmanship + Advocacy & Communities
    • Strength: Expert validation + newcomer amplification
      • Example: Co-created fragrance with expert community ‚Üí viral launch
        • Best For: Dual target balance, time-based strategy

    COMBO D: All Three (Product + Tech + Experience)
    • Strength: Comprehensive, hardest to copy
      • Example: Proprietary juice + personalized discovery + connected ecosystem
        • Best For: Maximum undupability, ambitious vision
          • Risk: Complex execution, feasibility questions

    AVOID: Advocacy & Communities alone (not enough substance)



    DAY 13-14: STRATEGIC THESIS DEVELOPMENT


    Deliverable: One-Page Strategic Thesis

    Template:


    
        STRATEGIC THESIS: [PROJECT NAME]

        TARGET BRAND: [YSL / Lanc√¥me / Prada / etc.]

        STRATEGIC OPPORTUNITY:
        [One paragraph describing the Eldorado opportunity + dupe threat]

        TARGET CONSUMER:
        Primary: [Expert or Newcomer - be specific]
        Secondary: [The other segment - explain progression]

        PLAYING FIELDS:
        1. [Primary playing field]
        2. [Secondary playing field]
        3. [Tertiary if applicable]

        CORE INSIGHT:
        [The "aha!" that makes this innovation necessary]
