    VIDEO SCRIPT FRAMEWORK

    5 Questions. 3 Minutes. Maximum Impact.

    The team video submission requires answering 5 specific questions that judges use to evaluate your team dynamics. Each question is worth 5 points on a scale of: 0 (Not Observed), 2 (Observed), 5 (Strongly Observed).

    THE 5 QUESTIONS

    # Criteria Question Time
    1 JUDGMENT What guided your decision-making in complex situations? ~35 sec
    2 RESILIENCE What were the hurdles during the project and how did the team overcome them? ~35 sec
    3 AMBITION What were the vision and long-term goals of your project? ~35 sec
    4 EMPATHY How do you support each other as a team? ~35 sec
    5 LEARNING AGILITY Did you encounter unfamiliar topics and how did you deal with it? ~35 sec

    QUESTION 1: JUDGMENT

    "What guided your decision-making in complex situations?"

    Answer Structure

    Element What to Include
    PRINCIPLE State the guiding value that drove decisions
    CONFLICT Describe a specific moment of competing options
    PROCESS How you evaluated (data, user feedback, debate)
    DECISION What you chose and WHY
    VALIDATION How you confirmed it was right

    Sample Answer

    "Our north star was always 'would this genuinely serve someone's emotional need?' When we faced a crossroads‚Äîwhether to lead with cutting-edge AI technology or lead with the human story of bottling memories‚Äîwe went back to the L'Or√©al Luxe insight reports. They showed us that Exception category buyers seek emotional connection over technical specs. We chose to lead with memory, with AI as the invisible enabler. This proved right when we tested our positioning‚Äîpeople didn't ask 'how does the AI work?' They asked 'can I really bottle my grandmother's garden?' That told us we'd made the right call."

    Breakdown: Principle: Emotional service | Conflict: Tech vs. Story | Process: L'Or√©al data | Decision: Memory-first | Validation: User response

    QUESTION 2: RESILIENCE

    "What were the hurdles during the project and how did the team overcome them?"

    Answer Structure

    Element What to Include
    OBSTACLE Name ONE specific, significant hurdle
    IMPACT What was at stake / how it felt
    PIVOT The specific action you took to overcome
    TEAM How you supported each other through it
    OUTCOME What you achieved because of the challenge

    Sample Answer

    "Our biggest hurdle came when we realized our original concept‚Äîa generic 'mood-based' fragrance selector‚Äîalready existed in the market. Two weeks of work, and we were back to zero. It was genuinely disheartening. But we gave ourselves 48 hours: each of us went deep into different research‚Äîcompetitor analysis, consumer pain points, L'Or√©al's tech capabilities. When we reconvened, [Name] brought the insight that changed everything: 'What if the input isn't a mood quiz‚Äîit's a personal photograph?' That collision of desperation and fresh research gave us MEMOIR. The setback forced us to find something truly original instead of settling for adequate."

    Breakdown: Obstacle: Concept already existed | Impact: 2 weeks lost | Pivot: 48-hour research sprint | Team: Divided & conquered | Outcome: Found true innovation

    QUESTION 3: AMBITION

    "What were the vision and long-term goals of your project?"

    Answer Structure

    Element What to Include
    VISION Bold, clear articulation of the ultimate goal
    WHY The larger impact beyond the competition
    SCALE How big this could become (numbers, reach)
    PERSONAL Why YOUR team cares about this
    LEGACY What you want this to create in the world

    Sample Answer

    "Our vision is to make every meaningful human memory preservable through scent. This matters because fragrance is the only sense directly wired to emotional memory‚Äîyet bespoke perfumery has been locked behind ‚Ç¨3,000 price tags and six-month wait times. We see MEMOIR reaching millions of people who want to bottle their wedding day, their grandmother's kitchen, their first apartment. The ‚Ç¨7.5B Exception market is growing 29% annually, and MEMOIR could capture ‚Ç¨130M by Year 5. But honestly? Each of us has a memory we wish we could return to. That's not market research‚Äîthat's personal. We want to transform fragrance from something you buy into something you create."

    Breakdown: Vision: Preserve any memory | Why: Democratize bespoke | Scale: ‚Ç¨130M Year 5 | Personal: Own memories | Legacy: Create, not buy

    QUESTION 4: EMPATHY

    "How do you support each other as a team?"

    Answer Structure

    Element What to Include
    DYNAMIC How your team naturally operates (complementary strengths)
    MOMENT A concrete example of support in action
    WHO Name names, show individual contributions
    VULNERABLE Acknowledge a struggle and how team responded
    BOND What this revealed about your team

    Sample Answer

    "We work because we balance each other. [Name] is our challenger‚Äîconstantly asking 'but why would someone actually pay for this?' [Name] is our synthesizer‚Äîtaking three conflicting ideas and finding the thread. I tend to keep us on timeline when we spiral into tangents. When [Name] was overwhelmed with finals during our financial modeling phase, we didn't wait to be asked‚Äî[Name] and I split their sections and delivered drafts for them to refine later. We've learned that saying 'I'm struggling' isn't weakness‚Äîit's how we stay ahead of problems. This project showed us we're not just teammates. We genuinely want each other to succeed, not just the project."

    Breakdown: Dynamic: Challenger/Synthesizer/Timekeeper | Moment: Finals overlap | Who: Named each person | Vulnerable: "I'm struggling" | Bond: Beyond the project

    QUESTION 5: LEARNING AGILITY

    "Did you encounter unfamiliar topics and how did you deal with it?"

    Answer Structure

    Element What to Include
    GAP Specific knowledge/skill you lacked at the start
    APPROACH How you went about learning (methods, sources)
    DIVISION How you divided learning across the team
    APPLICATION How you applied new knowledge to the project
    GROWTH What you can now do that you couldn't before

    Sample Answer

    "None of us had backgrounds in perfumery science, AI image recognition, or luxury pricing strategy. Three completely foreign domains. We divided and conquered: [Name] became our fragrance expert‚Äîstudying how visual-olfactive mapping works, interviewing the ISIPCA Grasse methodology. [Name] went deep on L'Or√©al's existing tech‚ÄîScent-Sation, Osmobloom, ModiFace‚Äîto understand what's actually feasible. I focused on Exception category economics and the dupe-proof positioning. Every week we taught each other what we'd learned. The result? We can now credibly discuss olfactive accords, AI accuracy rates, and ‚Ç¨7.5B market dynamics. We didn't just research‚Äîwe became conversant. That's knowledge we'll carry forward regardless of Brandstorm."

    Breakdown: Gap: 3 foreign domains | Approach: Divide & teach | Division: Fragrance/Tech/Business | Application: Built credible concept | Growth: Now conversant experts

    KEY PRINCIPLES FOR FULL MARKS (5 POINTS)

    Principle Why It Matters
    Name names "When [Name] was struggling..." shows real team awareness
    Be specific "Two weeks before deadline" beats "during the project"
    Show vulnerability Admit what was hard, don't oversell
    Concrete outcomes Numbers, decisions made, results achieved
    Natural delivery Know the content, don't recite word-for-word
    Time it 35 sec √ó 5 = 175 sec, leaving buffer for transitions

    SCORING DIFFERENTIATORS

    Score What It Looks Like
    0 - Not Observed Vague, generic, no specific example, reads like a script
    2 - Observed Has an example but lacks depth, doesn't show team dynamic
    5 - Strongly Observed Specific moment + named individuals + emotional honesty + concrete outcome + natural delivery

    VIDEO TIMING BREAKDOWN

    Section Time Content
    Introduction 0:00 - 0:10 Team intro, names
    Question 1: Judgment 0:10 - 0:45 Decision-making principles
    Question 2: Resilience 0:45 - 1:20 Overcoming hurdles
    Question 3: Ambition 1:20 - 1:55 Vision and goals
    Question 4: Empathy 1:55 - 2:30 Team support
    Question 5: Learning 2:30 - 3:00 Handling unfamiliar topics

    IMPORTANT REMINDER

    The video is about your TEAM, not your innovation idea. Focus on how you worked together, not on selling MEMOIR. The judges already know your concept‚Äîthey want to see the humans behind it.

    ‚Üë
